ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Asynchronous assignments in a "flipped-model" of learning (class time is for practice and questions, and we are expected to learn outside of the classroom)
Synchronous virtual lecture, virtual seminar
N/A
Synchronous sessions Monday, Wednesday, and Friday with asynchronous class materials/assignments on Tuesday/Thursday.
This class was taught synchronously three days a week and asynchronously two days a week.
The core of class was virtual seminars/discussions, supplemented by prerecorded lectures and textbook videos.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much about ASL, as well as Deaf culture. This class mainly emphasized learning the foundations of ASL which included vocabulary, grammatical structure, and an introduction to classifiers. We also focused heavily on Deaf culture's ties to ASL and how ASL is unique and separate from Spoken English.

In this class, I not only learned how to communicate through American Sign Language, but I also gained insights into Deaf Culture and the Deaf Community. The skills I learned in this class are vital to communicating through ASL, and I believe I can use the skills I learned in this class in the future to communicate to others without speaking.
I learned a lot of basic ASL skills, such as fingerspelling, glossing, vocabulary, and grammar. We also learned a lot about Deaf communities and culture.
I learned the principles of ASL 1 and am confident moving forward.
I learned valuable skills for American Sign Language including basic vocabulary and fingerspelling. Additionally, I learned much about Deaf culture.
Basic ASL vocabulary and grammatical skills, learn to communicate with others about yourself and ask them questions
fingerspelling, ASL grammar, beginner level vocabulary
This was a great introduction into American Sign Language. It covered both the grammar and language of ASL, but also delved into Deaf culture. It was a very interesting class and incredibly engaging.
I made huge strides in my ASL knowledge, and additionally gained a deeper understanding of Deaf culture.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths of this course include the overall high level of engagement and organization by Dr.K, who has experience prior to this semester with teaching ASL online! From day 1, the canvas page for ASL is super clear with the assignments, deadlines, and expectations for every week. I have never seen such high levels of organization from a professor  and it made the world of difference when it came to my personal learning experience. By encouraging a "flipped-model" of learning, Dr. K was able to retain a high level of engagement in the course. Every week's learning outside of the classroom was reasonable, and Dr.K was always very helpful with questions. While there were many assignments, they were split up into small assignments spread out over the course of the week, allowing students multiple opportunities to practice all we had learned.

A strength in this course was the fact that there were about 12 people in the class, and so our professor was easily able to communicate with each of us individually, and we were able to watch our classmates grow in their skills and communicate with them easily without being confused. A weakness of this class was that it was conducted virtually, and so there were some skills (like eye-contact), that we could not really work on because the class was virtual. Of course though, I understand that with the world's current situation, there was no other option.

Dr. Guynes was very understanding and accomodating to her students, which made the class fun and not stressful. We did many activities, such as bingo or virtual games, that made learning ASL very fun and interactive!  The assignments were also well organized and helpful for learning vocabulary and grammar. She gave lots of helpful feedback on our assignments. One minor weakness is that there was not a lot of time to practice conversations with the class, but I understand that there were limitations due to the virtual format.
Dr. K is amazing! She really cares about student understanding and appeals to many different learning styles.

The course work is very engaging and interactive, even while done online. This was my only class that I felt I paid full attention to during meeting times. I can't think of any weaknesses of the class.

Strengths: Dr.K's materials are easy to engage with, she is always open to questions and makes herself very available to students, the course is broken down into helpful units that are organized by theme, just really fun learning environment with games and conversations. Weaknesses: honestly none, Dr. K is a gem and this class is awesome

strengths: the professor! one of my favorite professors I've had at Yale, the class is very structured so you always know what to expect on a given day
weaknesses: none
This class was very well organized, and you are always given clear feedback. Overall, it was an excellent class.

This was far and away my strongest class since the beginning of the pandemic. I loved Dr. K's teaching style  I think she was incredibly skilled at managing the Zoom discussions, and I really appreciated her embrace of tools uniquely available to a virtual classroom, e.g. breakout rooms, google docs, shared google projects, her interactive use of powerpoint, etc. I took another Yale language course in person a few years ago and remember that professor also having success with fun lessons, but I never would've expected Dr. K to succeed in this way online; she blew my expectations out of the water. It's the only class I've had consistent fun in since we moved online, although I've enjoyed others. Can't say enough good things about Dr. K.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Every two weeks, we created a video log of sentences using the new vocabulary signs we learned that week. I found this to be extremely helpful, especially in a group with other students. It allowed me to meet new people, practice my sign production, and receive feedback from Dr. K that would further strengthen my learning. Additionally, the flipped-model of learning was very helpful to maximize the amount of class-time that was spent doing other fun things (such as playing bingo and other games with new vocab) and practicing!

Definitely the fact that you could mute yourself on zoom was beneficial to this class -- it really helped with the full immersion aspect of this class, and personally I believe it helped me. Other than this, looking at my professor from just the one angle sometimes made it difficult to learn the sign she was producing, and there were several times when I didn't quite understand the word she was producing.

Dr. Guynes had lots of virtual games that we played as a class, which made learning very engaging. The assignments and projects were well designed to be completed virtually. She also would give us 5-minute breaks in the middle of class, which was very helpful for preventing Zoom fatigue. It did require having a stable Internet source and decent camera quality to fully participate in the class, which was difficult sometimes since my Internet would not be great or other students' video was laggy, which would make it hard to see other people signing.
N/A
The courses handled the online Zoom format very well. There were some cases in which recording videos for submission was difficult, but the professor was very helpful in figuring them out.
All of the aspects of synchronous and asynchronous learning were successful and helpful! Dr.K was also really great about being available and open to questions.

This class was adapted very well for an online learning platform. The synchronous meetings required attendance and engagement was very high. The asynchronous work helped enhance the live classes, as well.
I think comprehensively answered by #4.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would 10000% recommend this course to any student interested in learning ASL and about Deaf culture! ASL 1 with Dr.K has been such an amazing experience, and I feel like I have learned so much.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to other students. Not only was it engaging, but I felt that I was actually learning a valuable skill that I can use outside of the classroom. Additionally, Professor Guynes was incredibly supportive and helpful all throughout the year, and so I really enjoyed her class and would definitely take it again if I could.

I would highly recommend this class! It was super interesting learning how to sign and about Deaf culture. The assignments and projects were very engaging and fun to do. The class also felt very laid-back but also engaging, so it never felt stressful.
Yes! The Professor, the outline, everything was organized and functional.
If you have any interest in learning ASL at all, I would highly recommend this course. Very good introduction to the language, but do not expect fluency from just one course.
YES! Such an incredible opportunity to learn about a beautiful and complicated language. If you are interested in ASL and get the chance to take this class, it's a must!!!

I absolutely would recommend this course, especially if you like a structured class. I never went to class unsure of what was going to happen that day, she always clearly outlined what we were going to do in a given week, and if plans changed, she would send announcements.
I would definitely recommend this course. It was very interesting and a pleasure to learn from Dr. K.
Highly recommend! Dr. K is so, so terrific, and makes the work engaging, fun, and rewarding. Her use of online tools was spectacular.
